pronunciation: IMPU'TE, [Latin imputo; in and puto, to think, to reckon; properly, to set, to put, to throw to or on.]

definitions.text:
1. To charge; attribute; the account of; generally ill, sometimes good. We impute crimes, sins, trespasses, faults, blame, etc., the guilty persons. We impute wrong actions bad motives, ignorance, folly rashness. We impute misfortunes miscarriages imprudence.And therefore it was imputed him forrighteousness. Romans 4:8.
2. To attribute; ascribe.I have read book imputed lord Bathurst.
3. To one what does not belong him.It has been held that Adam's sin is imputed all hisposterity.Thy meritImputed shall absolve them who renounceTheir own both righteous unrighteous deeds.
